message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, hoarseness of the voice is the most common side effect of inhaled corticosteroids. Suppression of the HPA axis is a possible but less common adverse effect that may occur with long-term use of high-dose corticosteroids. Steroid psychosis and short stature are also possible but much less common adverse effects of long-term, high-dose corticosteroid use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common adverse effect of inhaled corticosteroids is hoarseness of voice due to local action in the oropharynx. Suppression of HPA axis is a possible adverse effect but is rare at low doses. Steroid psychosis and short stature are also possible but less likely in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, hoarseness of voice is most likely to occur as a side effect of ICS therapy in children. Suppression of the hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis is a potential adverse effect, but it is less common with low-dose ICS therapy. Steroid psychosis and short stature are not common adverse effects of ICS therapy.

We refer to Mayo Clinic's article on inhaled corticosteroids for help. Hoarseness of voice is a common side effect of inhaled corticosteroids. Suppression of HPA axis can occur with long-term use but is rare with low doses. Steroid psychosis is very rare and usually occurs with high doses. Short stature is a concern with long-term use in children, but low-dose short-term use is unlikely to cause this side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inhaled corticosteroids can cause hoarseness of voice as a common side effect, but suppression of the HPA axis, steroid psychosis, and short stature are less common. The pediatrician should discuss the potential benefits and side effects of ICS therapy with the parents and monitor the boy's growth, bone density, and adrenal function regularly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, hoarseness of voice is the most likely adverse effect of corticosteroid therapy, especially in the case of inhaled corticosteroids. Suppression of HPA axis and short stature are possible, but less common, adverse effects of corticosteroid therapy, especially if given in high doses or for prolonged periods of time. Steroid psychosis is a rare but serious adverse effect and is more common with systemic rather than inhaled corticosteroids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most likely adverse effect of inhaled corticosteroids is hoarseness of voice. Suppression of HPA axis is a possible adverse effect but it is less common in low doses of inhaled corticosteroids. Steroid psychosis and short stature are also less likely to occur with low-dose inhaled corticosteroids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most likely corticosteroid-related adverse effect in this case is hoarseness of voice. Suppression of HPA axis can occur with long-term use of high-dose steroids but is less likely with low-dose inhaled steroids. Steroid psychosis and short stature are also potential adverse effects but are less common and less likely to occur with low-dose inhaled steroids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hoarseness of voice is the most likely adverse effect of inhaled corticosteroids in pediatric patients. Suppression of HPA axis is a potential adverse effect but is less likely at low doses. Steroid psychosis and short stature are rare adverse effects of long-term or high-dose corticosteroid therapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While all of the listed side effects are possible with corticosteroid use, hoarseness of voice is the most likely adverse effect. Suppression of the HPA axis is a potential complication with long-term use, but is usually reversible upon discontinuation. Steroid psychosis and short stature are more commonly associated with high-dose or prolonged use of corticosteroids.
